page.title: 02Carlingwark Loch 1
page.content: Carlingwark Loch is one of the main attractions of Castle Douglas. The name Carlingwark Loch comes from the Gaelic word Caer meaning fort and wark is the old Scots word for work. In the bronze age crannogs were built in the loch for fear of attack and they were used as a sort of fort. Hence the word Caer. Somewhere in the loch there are causeways leading to these sunken crannogs. There are many small islands in Carlinwark Loch. Sometimes when festivities are held coloured lights are hung round the larger islands as well as round the shore of the loch. The level of the loch used to rise and fall a lot, sometimes the loch flooded as far up as Marle Street. But since the Hydro Electric Power Scheme was established at Glenlochar, the level has been controlled. It is impossible
